entry.title: Product Compliance in SAP Cloud ERP Private | 2025 Release
entry.content:
Welcome to our deep dive into the latest advancements for Product Compliance in SAP Cloud ERP Private 2025 release. I am thrilled to walk you through the key highlights for this release, collected with close collaboration with our product management teams focused on asset management.

This collection is part of SAP features released on October 8, 2025

 

These are the topics that are covered:

Product Compliance Foundation

  • Continuous content delivery for product marketability and safety data sheet compliance requirements

Dangerous Goods Management

  • Visualization of information for ADR and RID 1.1.3.6
  • Output scenarios for additional dangerous goods transport documents
  • Integration of mixed loading checks for dangerous goods in sales, delivery, and transportation management
  • Printing dangerous-goods freight documents in transportation management

Safety Data Sheet and Label Management

  • Supporting multi-component products for two or more products in the safety data sheet process
  • Support for branded products in the safety data sheet process

 

Product Compliance Foundation

Continuous content delivery for product marketability and safety data sheet compliance requirements

Business Background

Staying current with ever-changing global regulations is a significant challenge for businesses that market and ship products worldwide. A delay in adopting new compliance rules for product marketability or safety data sheets can lead to shipment stops, fines, and market access issues. Companies need a way to receive and implement these updates without being tied to a major software release cycle, ensuring business continuity and unwavering compliance.


Key Feature


With this innovation, we enable continuous content delivery for product marketability (PMA) and safety data sheet (SDS) compliance requirements via the SAP Regulatory Content Service. This decouples regulatory updates from the main software release schedule. Now you can receive the latest rule sets as they are released, allowing you to remain up to date with the newest regulations. This ensures your product portfolio stays compliant without needing to wait for or implement a new SAP S/4HANA Cloud release.

Image #1: Compliance Requirements Versions

 

Dangerous Goods Management

Visualization of information for ADR and RID 1.1.3.6

Business Background

When transporting dangerous goods, specific exemptions can apply under certain conditions, such as the limited quantity provisions in ADR and RID 1.1.3.6 for road and rail transport. For logistics planners and transport operators, having clear and immediate visibility into whether a shipment qualifies for such exemptions is crucial for ensuring both safety and regulatory compliance, while also optimizing transport costs and processes.

 

Key Feature

To provide this visibility, the "View Markings and Labels; Dangerous Goods" app has been renamed to "Dangerous Goods Information; For the Value Chain" and enhanced significantly. This app now visualizes information related to the ADR and RID 1.1.3.6 agreements, making it easy to see exemption applicability. This feature establishes the foundation for integrating this data into freight units, freight orders, and bookings, helping your teams comply with complex dangerous goods regulations more effectively.

 

Image #2: Dangerous Goods Information – For the Value Chain


Output scenarios for additional dangerous goods transport documents

Business Background

Operating a global supply chain requires adherence to a diverse and extensive array of transport regulations, each with unique documentation requirements. Manually generating specific dangerous goods notes for different countries and transport modes is inefficient and increases the risk of errors, which can cause transport delays and compliance failures.

 

Key Feature

This release introduces a host of new output scenarios to support a wide range of dangerous goods transport documents. This includes support for UNRTDG, ADG, ANTT, NOM, NCh382, NZS, SANS, JT/T 617.3, and ADN notes. You can now use these scenarios to view descriptions in the Classify Packaged Dangerous Good app and leverage public APIs to create compliant transport documents in external systems. This allows you to optimize the utilization of the rich dangerous goods information managed within SAP S/4HANA.

Image #3: Output scenarios for additional dangerous goods transport documents

 

Integration of mixed loading checks for dangerous goods in sales, delivery, and transportation management

Business Background

A critical aspect of transport safety is preventing the co-loading of incompatible dangerous goods. These mixed loading prohibitions are strictly enforced, and violations can lead to severe accidents and legal penalties. To mitigate this risk, businesses require systematic checks to be performed early and consistently throughout the logistics process, from sales to final transport execution.

 

Key Feature

This enhancement integrates dangerous goods mixed loading checks directly into the core logistics value chain. The system now automatically performs these checks on sales orders and outbound deliveries, as well as within Transportation Management for freight units, freight orders, and bookings. This proactive validation helps you prevent the execution of noncompliant and unsafe transports, safeguarding your people, assets, and brand reputation.

 

Image #4: Analyse Delivery Logs

 

Image #5: Display Logs



Printing dangerous-goods freight documents in transportation management

Business Background

To legally transport dangerous goods, shipments must be accompanied by freight documents containing specific, accurate dangerous goods information. Generating these documents separately from standard freight paperwork is inefficient and creates opportunities for inconsistency and error, jeopardizing compliance.

 

Key Feature

You can now print relevant dangerous goods information together with your standard freight documents directly from Transportation Management. This release provides compliant document templates for key regulations, including the ADR dangerous goods note for European road transport, the RID note for European rail, U.S. and Canadian bills of lading, and the IMDG declaration for ocean transport. This integration ensures you can provide freight documents that are fully compliant with the regulations of various countries.

Image#6: Process Request from Logistics

 

 

Safety Data Sheet and Label Management

Supporting multi-component products for two or more products in the safety data sheet process

Business Background

Many industries sell products as kits or sets that contain multiple distinct chemical components, each of which may legally require its own Safety Data Sheet (SDS). Managing and distributing the correct SDS for every component to the customer can be a complex and manual task, risking incomplete communication of safety information.

 

Key Feature

To address this, we now provide the ability to send safety data sheets for multiple components of a product at the same time. When a product is comprised of two or more items requiring an SDS, the system can now group and transmit all relevant documents in a single, consolidated process. This improves your compliance with SDS regulations and ensures your customers receive complete and accurate safety information efficiently.

Image #7: Safety Data Sheets

 

Image#8: Components



Support for branded products in the safety data sheet process

Business Background

Companies often market an identical substance or mixture under various brand names or trade names to serve different markets or customer segments. Sending the same SDS to a customer multiple times, once for each branded product they purchase, is redundant and can create unnecessary administrative work and confusion for the recipient.

Key Feature

This feature introduces support for branded products in the safety data sheet shipment process. You can now configure the system to manage SDS distribution at the branded-product level. This includes deriving the product name on the SDS from the branded product information. This intelligent handling helps you avoid sending redundant SDS documents to customers, streamlining your compliance processes and improving the customer experience.

Image#9: Branded Product Names

entry.title: SAP S4 HANA Finance integration and Use case with SAP Joule
entry.content:
What Is SAP Joule?

SAP Joule is SAP’s AI copilot embedded across its cloud applications. It offers four interaction types—Transactional, Navigational, Informational, and Analytical—that let users perform business tasks via natural language within SAP environments. It understands user context, roles, permissions, and remains secure by design. It can also ground responses in your own business documents.

 How SAP Joule works in Public vs. Private Cloud is one of the most important considerations for finance teams (especially in FICO) deciding on adoption.

Here’s a structured view:

 SAP Joule in Public vs. Private Cloud

Deployment & Integration

  • Public Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition)
    • Joule is natively embedded and updated by SAP automatically.
    • Integration with SAP FICO apps (GL, AP, AR, Asset Accounting, Controlling) is out of the box.
    • No additional installation required - users just activate and configure.
  • Private Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition)
    • Joule can be enabled, but may require additional setup and integration.
    • Some Joule features might lag behind public cloud, because public gets innovations first.
    • Still integrates with FICO, but might require extra configuration & tenant connections to SAP BTP.

Feature Availability

  • Public Cloud
    • Joule supports all 4 interaction types (Transactional, Navigational, Informational, Analytical) directly in Fiori apps.
    • Example in FICO: “Post vendor invoice” → transaction executes directly.
    • Faster delivery of Joule Agents and Joule Studio.
  • Private Cloud
    • Informational & Analytical features available early (queries, reports, insights).
    • Transactional flows may require enablement through custom skills/agents.
    • Joule Studio can still be connected via SAP BTP, but adoption speed depends on customer’s upgrade cycle.

Customization & Extensibility

  • Public Cloud
    • Limited custom coding—extensions must go through SAP BTP side-by-side development.
    • Joule skills/agents are mostly standardized.
    • Great if you want speed & standardization.
  • Private Cloud
    • More flexibility: you can create custom FICO processes, reports, and Joule agents.
    • Easier to integrate with on-prem or legacy systems.
    • Suited for companies with complex finance processes.

Data Security & Residency

  • Public Cloud
    • Data is hosted on SAP-managed hyperscalers (AWS, Azure, GCP, SAP DCs).
    • Joule queries financial data via secure APIs; customers rely on SAP’s compliance.
  • Private Cloud
    • You control hosting, location, and more of the security stack.
    • Some finance-heavy industries (banking, defense, public sector) may prefer this for regulatory reasons.

Upgrade & Innovation

  • Public Cloud
    • Quarterly upgrades → Joule features arrive first and fastest.
    • Example: New Joule Agents for FICO tasks (like dispute resolution) appear immediately.
  • Private Cloud
    • Annual upgrades (with optional Feature Packs).
    • Joule features arrive later—innovation follows public cloud by a few cycles.

 Comparison Table

Aspect

Public Cloud

Private Cloud

Availability

Native, out-of-the-box

Needs setup, later adoption

Updates

Quarterly, fastest innovations

Annual/controlled upgrades

Customization

Limited, BTP-based

Flexible, deep customizations

Security

SAP-managed hyperscalers

Customer-controlled

FICO Use Cases

Immediate transactional & analytical support

Strong for complex, regulated finance scenarios

Joule Studio

Fully available

Available via BTP, more flexible

 Which is Better for FICO?

  • Public Cloud → Best if you want rapid innovation, standard finance processes, faster AI adoption.
  • Private Cloud → Best if you need deep customization, strict compliance, hybrid IT integration.

 SAP Joule version requirements for S/4HANA Cloud editions (Public and Private):

  1. SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • Joule arrived as part of the Public Cloud starting around Q3 2024, and is embedded in all releases thereafter, including 2408 (August 2024) and onward.
  • While Joule is built into these releases, you still need proper entitlement and authorization to use it; this may require activation via your SAP admin or account executive.
  • There are setup guides available detailing how to activate Joule once entitlement is granted.

In Summary:

If your system is on Public Cloud release 2408 (Aug 2024) or later, Joule is already supported—assuming you've got the right access and permissions.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition

  • Joule is available in the Private Cloud as well, but requires setup and configuration. It's not automatically active—you must enable it via SAP BTP and Joule Studio.
  • Technical prerequisites include ensuring the UI5 version in your system meets or exceeds the minimum required for Joule integration. The specific UI5 version will depend on your release; you can consult SAP documentation for exact details.

In Summary:

Private Cloud systems can support Joule—but you must set it up, ensure the UI5 stack is compatible, and configure the feature via BTP.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise (Classic)

  • Joule is not supported on on-premise S/4HANA. SAP has confirmed it's not on the current roadmap for classic on-premise systems.
  • There’s a planned strategy—possibly coming Q1 2025—to enable Joule via SAP Build Work Zone, BTP, and Joule Studio even for on-prem systems. But as of now, Joule remains unavailable on-prem and unsupported.

High-Level Overview

Edition

Supported from (release)

Requirements

Public Cloud

2408 (Aug 2024) onward

Needs entitlement/authorization & activation

Private Cloud

Post-2024 releases

Requires UI5 prerequisites + BTP/Joule Studio setup

On-Premise (classic)

Not supported (as of now)

No Joule availability; roadmap may include future BTP-based solution

Summary:

  • Public Cloud: Joule is supported starting with 2408 onward—activate it via entitlement.
  • Private Cloud: Joule is available but not automatic—requires UI compliance + setup via BTP.
  • On-Premise: Joule is not supported yet; no built-in version availability.

Here’s how SAP Joule, SAP’s generative AI assistant, can be applied specifically within the SAP FICO (Finance & Controlling) domain:

SAP Joule Application in FICO

  • Transactional Interactions

Joule allows users to perform CRUD operations and manage financial documents via natural language—imagine asking:

  • “Post a vendor invoice of $5,000 to account X with due date Y.”
  • “Show me the status of PO invoice 10234.”
    While SAP hasn't yet released out-of-the-box FICO conversational flows, Joule’s transactional model supports this kind of interaction across cloud applications.
  • Navigational Interactions

Instead of navigating through menus to reach Fiori apps like “Display GL Account Balances,” you could simply ask:

  • “Where can I review G/L balances?”
    Joule will direct you to the relevant screen.
  • Informational Interactions

Straight answers instead of digging through help docs. You can ask:

  • “What’s the difference between cost center and profit center accounting?”
  • “Explain account determination for automatic postings.”
    Joule will deliver concise explanations, referencing SAP documentation or your own policy documents.

Analytical Interactions

Joule bridges your natural-language queries to data analytics:

  • “Show me quarterly expense trends per cost center.”
  • “Which cost centers exceeded budget last quarter?”
    It returns charts, metrics, or dashboards—leveraging SAP Analytics Cloud integration.

Advanced: Joule Agents & Studio

Joule Agents

SAP has introduced AI agents—autonomous actors capable of executing complex, multi-step workflows across business functions. In FICO, custom agents could:

  • Automate dispute resolution: Collaborate across finance and service teams to validate discrepancies and propose corrections.
  • Cash collection workflows: Analyze overdue invoices, coordinate with collections, and initiate follow-ups.
    These agents are part of SAP’s cross-functional automation strategy.

Joule Studio (within SAP Build)

No-code/low-code tool to create custom skills or agents tailored for your FICO needs:

  • Build a skill to automatically generate internal financial reports, or trigger approval workflows.
  • Automate vendor reconciliation or recurring postings by designing tailored AI agents.
    These skills and agents integrate across SAP and non-SAP systems.

Summary Table

Joule Capability

FICO Use Case Example

Transactional

Post invoices, check payment status via natural language

Navigational

Ask “Where to view Cost Center Reports?”

Informational

Clarify financial terms or posting rules

Analytical

Generate trends and KPI charts using SAC

Agents & Studio

Automate dispute resolution, cash collection, approvals

Key Benefits in FICO

  • Boost Productivity: Save time by speaking instead of clicking through screens.
  • Reduce Errors: Leverage conversational clarity and auto-generated documents.
  • Improve Insights: Conduct data reviews and root cause analysis through simple dialogue.
  • Automate Complex Workflows: Agents handle multi-step tasks such as reconciliations or approvals automatically.

Real-World Usage Context -- Caveats

While SAP is rapidly developing Joule’s capabilities, many implementations remain in pilot or PoC stages. Users in forums report limited early usage, primarily for basic navigation or queries.

Here are concrete FICO scenarios where you could pilot SAP Joule and even extend it with Joule Agents / Studio:

 Pilot Scenarios in SAP FICO

  1. Invoice & Payment Handling
  • Ask Joule:
    “Post an invoice for vendor ABC with $12,000 due in 30 days.”
  • Joule Action: Creates the posting, validates tax code, and confirms with you.
  • Extension with Agent: Automate follow-up—if payment not cleared by due date, Joule Agent triggers a reminder email or escalates.
  1. Month-End Close Assistant
  • Ask Joule:
    “What are the pending tasks for month-end close?”
  • Joule Action: Lists open items (accruals, GR/IR clearing, reconciliations).
  • Extension with Agent: Automate recurring accrual postings and send alerts to approvers who are late in providing confirmations.
  1. Financial Analysis & Insights
  • Ask Joule:
    “Show me expense trend per cost center for last 6 months.”
  • Joule Action: Returns a chart (via SAC integration).
  • Extension with Agent: Forecast next quarter’s expenses and flag cost centers that may exceed budgets.
  1. Audit & Compliance Checks
  • Ask Joule:
    “List journal entries above $50,000 in the last quarter without approvals.”
  • Joule Action: Generates a filtered list.
  • Extension with Agent: Create an automated internal audit agent that periodically checks for compliance exceptions and notifies controllers.
  1. Treasury & Cash Management
  • Ask Joule:
    “What is today’s cash position?”
  • Joule Action: Summarizes bank balances, incoming/outgoing payments.
  • Extension with Agent: Auto-generate a daily treasury dashboard at 9 AM and send to CFO.
  1. Dispute & Collections Management
  • Ask Joule:
    “Show me customers with invoices overdue > 60 days.”
  • Joule Action: Lists overdue accounts.
  • Extension with Agent: An AI agent sends personalized payment reminders and schedules calls with collections staff.
  1. Budget vs. Actual Control
  • Ask Joule:
    “Which cost centers exceeded budget last quarter?”
  • Joule Action: Shows variances with drill-down.
  • Extension with Agent: Automatically notify budget owners when variances exceed a threshold (say 10%).

 How to Design in Joule Studio

In Joule Studio (within SAP Build) you can:

  1. Create a Skill → “Generate quarterly P&L by company code and send PDF to finance team.”
  2. Create an Agent → “Monitor overdue vendor payments and auto-initiate dunning.”
  3. Connect Non-SAP Apps → e.g., send approvals via MS Teams or Slack.

 

 This way, Joule moves from a copilot (answering queries) to a colleague (executing finance tasks for you).

 

Deep Dive on one of the real-world example: Vendor Invoice Posting with SAP Joule in Public vs Private Cloud.

 Example: Vendor Invoice Posting with Joule

 Scenario

A finance user wants to post a vendor invoice for Vendor 300012, amount $12,000, due in 30 days.

 Public Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition)

  • User says to Joule:
    “Post a vendor invoice of $12,000 for Vendor 300012, due in 30 days.
  • Joule Process:
    1. Understands the intent (“Create Vendor Invoice”).
    2. Pulls relevant master data (Vendor 300012 details, tax code, payment terms).
    3. Pre-fills the invoice screen in Fiori.
    4. User confirms → Invoice is posted.
  • Extras in Public Cloud:
    • Joule can immediately display the document number and due date schedule.
    • If connected to SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), Joule can also show how this impacts cash outflow forecast.
    • Minimal setup → available out-of-the-box.

 Private Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition)

  • User says to Joule:
     “Post a vendor invoice of $12,000 for Vendor 300012, due in 30 days.”
  • Joule Process:
    • Provide navigation → “Open FB60 (Vendor Invoice Entry)” or “Fiori App: Create Supplier Invoice.”
    • Pre-fill metadata only if integrated with custom Joule Skill via Joule Studio.
    1. Joule recognizes intent, but instead of direct posting, it may:
    2. User manually confirms or adjusts in the classic posting screen (e.g., FB60 / MIRO).
    3. Invoice is posted.
  • Extras in Private Cloud:
    • You can customize Joule Agent (via Joule Studio + BTP) to enforce company-specific validations (e.g., block invoices >$10,000 without 2 approvals).
    • Joule can connect to legacy non-SAP apps (like OCR invoice scanners or in-house workflow systems).
    • Requires more setup & governance compared to Public Cloud.

 Side-by-Side Comparison

Step

Public Cloud

Private Cloud

Activation

Native, plug-and-play

Needs setup & integration

Invoice Posting

Joule executes directly in Fiori app

Joule suggests navigation, may require custom agent for automation

Flexible, can embed custom compliance rules

Moderate (confirmation in screen, extra steps if no custom agent)

Key Takeaway:

  • In Public Cloud, Joule = speed + simplicity → perfect for companies with standard finance processes.
  • In Private Cloud, Joule = control + flexibility → better if you need extra compliance steps, custom posting logic, or hybrid integration.

entry.title: SAML+OAuth2 (PowerApps --> SAP)
entry.content:
• Overview
  • Basic setup
  • Postman test
  • SAP Integration Suite setup
  • Microsoft PowerPlatform test
  • Troubleshooting

Overview

This setup describes SAP data consumption (S/4HANA) in Microsoft PowerApps with user authentication using Microsoft EntraID. So you could login to Microsoft PowerApps with your EntraID account and use there data from S/4HANA.
If you're interested in the theory and architecture behind this setup, please read this excellent article written by Martin Pankraz.
Steps described here are compatible with S/4HANA On-premise, S/4HANA Private Cloud and ECC 6 EHP8, but some screens may look different as screenshots were captured in S/4HANA Private Cloud 2023.

Basic setup

Start by checking that all required services are enabled in T-Code SICF.

  • /sap/bc/webdynpro/sap/saml2
  • /sap/public/bc/sec/saml2
  • /sap/public/bc/sec/cdc_ext_service
  • /sap/public/myssocntl
  • /sap/bc/sec/oauth2/token

Open T-Code SAML2 and enable SAML support. Provider name could be any string, but must be URL compliant! It's best practice to use http://<SID><client>. Switch selection mode to automatic if you intent to use only one IDP.

Local provider is created. Download metadata needed for next steps.

Now go to EntraID and create Enterprise App of type "SAP NetWeaver".

On "Single sign-on" tab click "SAML". New blank configuration will be created. Use "Upload metadata file" button and select metadata file downloaded from SAP. This loads SAP's metadata into EntraID.

Edit "Reply URL" to point to Token service of OAuth2 and don't forget to set correct client in parameter "sap-client". "Sign on URL" could be any URL compliant string (ex. https://dummy.com).

Edit "Attributes & Claims". Click on "Unique User Identifier (Name ID)".

You have two options here, based on attribute that you like to use as user identifier.

  1. If you don't have any email address assigned to more than one user in SAP and you use email as UPN in EntraID, you could match EntraID and SAP user based on email. In this case select "Name identifier format" = "Email address" and "Source attribute" = "user.userprincipalname".
  2. Otherwise find source attribute that contains SAP username. Ex. sAMAccountName. For this scenario choose "Name identifier format" = "Unspecified".

Save and return to "Single sign-on" tab of your Enterprise App configuration. In "SAML Certificates" section download the certificate and federation metadata.

Go back to SAP backend and open T-Code SAML2. Switch to "Trusted Providers" tab and select "OAuth 2.0 Identity providers" under the "List of Trusted providers". Add a new provider using the metadata you just downloaded from EntraID.

In the next step, upload the certificate downloaded from EntraID. In the "Provider" and "Signature and Encryption" steps, click "Next" and then "Finish".

Edit the new trusted IDP and select the name format "Unspecified" or "E-mail", depending on the user mapping scenario. Scenario 1 is "E-mail", scenario 2 is "Unspecified".

Set the "User ID Mapping Mode" according to the scenario. For scenario 1 "email" or "Logon ID" for scenario 2.

Save and enable the configuration.

Open EntraID again and create new App registration (not Enterprise app) that will be used as client.

On "Authentication" tab, section "Platform configurations" click "Add a platform" and select "Web". Set "Redirect URIs" = "https://localhost:44326/signin-oidc" and select both tokens to be issued.

On "Certificates & secrets" tab generate new client secrete. Save the content of "Value" field as you can't access it later!

Next, on "API permissions" tab add a permission "Microsoft Graph" as delegated. Select "openid" (Sign users in).

On "Expose and API" tab add a scope. URI should be predefined. After clicking "Save" new configuration panel will be shown. Fill there "Scope name" = "user_impersonation" and switch consent to "Admins and users". Set some display name and description. Finally click "Add scope".

On the same tab add a client application. Set "Client ID" = "6bee4d13-fd19-43de-b82c-4b6401d174c3" and set our scope in "Authorized scopes". This fixed client ID is identifier of SAP OData connector in PowerApps platform.

Copy "Application (client) ID" from "Overview" tab.

Now switch to App registration (not Enterprise app) that corresponds to the server part (same name as our Enterprise app defined in the beginning). Go to "Expose and API" tab and add a client application. Add there copied client ID and set scope.

One again switch to SAP system. Create technical user for impersonation. This user must be type B (System) and has correct permission role assigned. You need these permissions:

  • S_RFC: RFC_TYPE=Function group, RFC_NAME=SYST, ACTVT=Execute
  • S_SCOPE: OA2_CLIENT=SOAUTH2 (set same as ID of technical user), OA2_SCOPE=<required_scopes> (start with "*" for testing and restrict later)

Call T-Code SOAUTH2. On the screen click "Create". Set ID of technical user as "OAuth 2.0 Client ID" and write some description.

In "Grant Type Setting" step select our trusted IDP from the list and set "Refresh Allowed".

In "Scope Assignment" step set some service that you'd like to expose.

Postman test

It's time for first test. You could use attached Postman collection. Edit variables of the collection.

Please also change service name and parameters in request number 4 based on your use case (if not calling BP OData service as in example).

Now open first call of the collection and send request. Ignore output and open console (bottom left corner). Copy whole link (without GET keyword) and paste it in the web browser. After successful EntraID login blank error page will be shown. Go to the address bar and copy content of parameter "access_token". Open request number 2 and paste token to the "assertion" parameter.

After sending request number 2 you should see "access_token" in the output. Open request number 3 and send it. If successfull you would get new (short) "access_token" and also "refresh_token" and correct "scope".

Finally open and send request number 4. You should see data from your service.

SAP Integration Suite setup

In order to use this setup from internet / public cloud you have to expose SAP AS over SAP Cloud Connector.

In case that you don't have SAP Integration Suite BTP subaccount already added in SAP Cloud Connector, please use official guide to add it: SAP Help Portal | SAP Online Help

Now go to the Cloud Connector subaccount and select "Cloud to On-Premises" in the left menu. On "Access Control" tab add new system (Mapping Virtual to Internal System). Backend type is "ABAP System", protocol "HTTPS". Fill in hostname and port of SAP AS.

Use same values for virtual host and port. Disable Principal Propagation and Certificate Logon as you don't need these in this scenario. Host in request header should be Virtual Host. Set SID (ex. I4A) as System ID.

Expose services (your OData) in "Resources" section. On this example I'm exposing whole system (don't do this with productive SAP AS!).

Open SAP Integration Suite and begin with setup there. In left menu select Configure -> APIs and select "API Providers" tab.

Create new provider. Fill some meaningful name on "Overview" tab. Switch to "Connection" tab and set "Type" = "On Premise", "Host" = <AS_ABAP_HOST>, "Port" = <AS_ABAP_PORT>, leave "Authentication" = "None". Set "sap-client" = <AS_ABAP_CLIENT> in Additional Properties.

Save provider and test connection. It should return "System is up and reachable. However, the ping check responded with code : 404; Message : Not found". That's correct state because we're calling base URL and not any reachable service.

Go to "Policy Templates" tab and import definition that's available in SAP Business Accelerator Hub. This policy needs some mapping. So switch to "Key Value Maps" tab and create new mapping (ex. name "I4ACLNT400_EntraID"). Use table bellow as an example.

Finally switch to "API Proxies" tab and create new proxy. Select your API Provider, set URL to OData service that you have in the scope. Define some name and title of proxy. API Base Path could be anything you like - it's simply prefix for OData calls to this service (ex. /sap/utility/odata).

Ignore error "Unable to fetch metadata" - it's normal as we didn't applied policy yet.

In the new API provider click "..." in top right corner and select "Policies". Again in top right corner click "Policy Template" -> "Apply". Select policy that you downloaded earlier and apply it. You should now see it under target endpoint's post flow.

Now go step by step through the policy. In second step (MapVariables) replace value of "mapIdentifier" with the name of your value map (ex. I4ACLNT400_EntraID). In steps "RefreshSAPToken", "fetchSAPOAuthToken" and "GetCSRFToken" change value of tag "APIProvider" from "PM1-via-SCC" to your provider name (ex. I4ACLNT400_NOAUTH).

Click "Update", "Save" and "Deploy".

Microsoft PowerPlatform test

Login to Microsoft PowerApps at Power Apps and switch to correct environment (if using more). In the left menu click "Flows" and create new cloud flow "Instant cloud flow". Fill some name and choose "Manually trigger a flow".

Add new step with connector "SAP OData", action "Read OData entity".

Set authentication type "Microsoft Entra ID Integrated (with APIM)". OData base URI is URL of you API Proxy service (ex. https://******.test.apimanagement.******.hana.ondemand.com/sap/utility/odata/BusinessPartner), Entra ID resource URI is API scope of client app (ex. api://b20e44f0-d88a-4558-8a53-b34484425e3f/user_impersonation). Set "API Key Name" = "APIKey (constant), "API Key Value" = <Client_secret> (ex. HZ48Q~NDBD38a4XW~************) and SAP's client name / password.

You should see Entra ID popup for login. After that service should be authenticated and entities readable.

Troubleshooting

In case you're struggling with the basic setup (Postman testing), start T-Code SEC_DIAG_TOOL_VIEWER and capture the login traffic. You can find errors there and search SAP for Me. Always double check that user calling API (your business user, not SOAUTH2) is valid and has correct permission assigned (check SU53 for errors).

If calling OData API from PowerApps fails immediately with authentication error, check EntraID tenant log for errors associated with your registered client app.

Sometimes it fails later in login process and this could be debuged on Integration Suite. Open definition of your API Proxy, click "Debug" (top right corner) and "Start Debug" (bottom right corner). Now call API from PowerApps, refresh debugged window and check for errors.

entry.title: Production Planning Monitor for Collective Evaluation of MPS Planning Results [Part 2]
entry.content:
[Blog Type: Hands-on Expertise]

[Blog Series: In the previous blog post Purchasing Planning Monitor for Collective Evaluation of MRP Planning Results [Part 1], the MRP Purchasing Planning Monitor focused on MRP products (purchasing product and intermediate product) was illustrated, while on this blog post the MPS Production Planning Monitor focused on MPS products (final product) is explained.]

 

Summary

This blog post describes how to build a planning monitoring tool to evaluate and manage the MPS results for multiple materials. This tool can show per material the historical consumption data – consumption-based planning – together with the stocks and requirements information – material requirements planning –, and the corresponding MRP created receipt elements to cover the shortages.

The target audience for this blog post will be consulting people, project team members, key users, and subject matter experts who are interested on the visualization of the MRP results.

 

Introduction

A typical customer requirement is to visualize the result of the MRP run for several materials in a report format, that is, they want MD04 for every material on a plant in a single screen. The purpose is to have an easy and fast way of identification of critical materials where the planner needs to take an action, and then being able to select the specific material and drill down into the stock, requirements and planning elements details. There is not a standard report available that would show a detailed display of stock/requirements list for multiple materials.

A collective MRP results view is normally something very difficult to build, as companies have thousands of materials per plant with different business cases concerning procurement types, planning strategies, production types, origin of the requirements, etc… Furthermore, the target information to be displayed is different depending on the user role:

  • As a production supervisor, buyer, sales executive or MRP controller, you want to access information on the stock/requirements situation of the material, and then gain an overview of the development of stock and requirements in the coming weeks.
  • As a production supervisor, you want to gain an overview of the MRP elements for in-house production (planned orders, production orders, dependent reservations) or of the MRP elements for a particular production line.
  • As a buyer, you want to check which purchase orders and purchase requisitions exist for a material for a particular vendor.
  • As a sales executive, you are only interested in the current sales orders for a particular customer for a material.
  • As an MRP controller, you are interested in available quantities based on sales orders that have actually been received and not on the basis of the planned independent requirements. You therefore want the planned independent requirements to be displayed, but do not want to change the available quantity if sales order exists.
  • As an MRP controller, you want to be informed about the requirements of bulk materials or materials that are planned using consumption-based planning, to check whether these requirements occur continually.

Another issue to consider is the requirement of some customers to manage historical consumption data together with the requirements information, thus allowing them to compare future needs with past consumptions on the same periods in the same single screen.

Therefore, having all these requirements and conditions in mind, we may think that building a collective tool to evaluate and manage the MRP results for multiple materials becomes a great challenge. This blog explains how this collective planning tool can be built for isolated and specific planning scenarios.

 

Evaluating the Planning Run on SAP S/4HANA

For Classic MRP, the available tools for checking the planning results are the following:

  • Stock/Requirements List
  • MRP List
  • Evaluation of the Planning Situation
  • Evaluation of the Planning Result
  • Planning Table for repetitive manufacturing

During the planning run, the system analyzes the requirements that exist for the planned materials and creates procurement or manufacturing elements to cover these requirements. The evaluations on these tools show all receipt and issue elements for a material in tabular form and enable you to gain a quick overview of the stock/requirements situation for the material as well as to branch into the processing function for the MRP elements for this material.

In the stock/requirements list, the most up-to-date stock and requirements situation is displayed. Changes that are made after the planning date are displayed directly, so the list is dynamic. The MRP list always displays the stock/requirements situation at the time of the last planning run. Changes that are made after the planning date are not taken into consideration, so the list is static.

The planning situation takes all changes in stock, receipts and issues that occur between planning runs into account (as in the stock/requirements list). The planning result displays the result of the last planning run (as in the MRP list). The main difference is that you set up a special evaluation layout for the formatting of the data in the planning result and planning situation. This layout defines which receipt and issue elements are displayed at which level of aggregation.

In SAP S/4HANA, the MRP Live is used, and we also have the MRP Cockpit Fiori Apps and the MPR Situation Handling. MRP Lists are gone with MRP Live due to the considerable performance improvement. The several available MRP Cockpit Fiori Apps display an overview of materials with possible stock shortages, and you can also drill down into a specific material to see the stock/requirements situation.

The new Fiori Apps for MRP evaluation are more visually appealing, and they contain features only available in Fiori, such as Demand-Driven MRP (DDMRP) and Predictive MRP (pMRP). Moreover, they are also supported in mobile devices.

On below table you can find a summary of the abovementioned MRP transactions or Fiori Apps:

Application

Description

Transaction MD04

Display Individual Stock/Requirements Situation

Transaction MD07

Display Collective Stock/Requirements Situation

Transaction MD05

Individual Display of MRP List

Transaction MD06

Collective Display of MRP List

Transaction MD44

Planning Situation

Transaction MD47

Collective Display for Planning Situation

Transaction MD45

Planning Result

Transaction MD46

Collective Display for Planning Result

Transaction MD48

Multi-Plant Planning Situation

Fiori App F0251A

Manage Material Coverage

Fiori App F2101A

Monitor Material Coverage

 

Customer Requirement for a Collective Evaluation of the MRP Planning Results

Customer business case was a small-sized food company with mainly a mass production environment using discrete manufacturing. Main finished products were fresh products sent to retailers to be sold on the supermarket’s shelf. Therefore, demand was seasonal but also with a special focus on daily consumption pattern.  The customer was interested on running the MRP with requirements based on forecast demand, but also considering the historical consumption of the last four weeks per day, to have the whole picture.

Since it was just a small company, there were only two main MRP responsible for the whole of the planning process and availability control for purchasing products, intermediate production and final product production. The two main areas of responsibility were MPS products, covering the final products to sale, and MRP products, covering the products for purchasing and intermediate production. On this blog we will focus on the MPS products; the MRP products were already covered on previous blog post Purchasing Planning Monitor for Collective Evaluation of MRP Planning Results.

The customer used a make-to-stock production (goods sold from stock) because of the following reasons:

  • The materials were produced independently of the sales orders.
  • The materials were not assigned to specific sales orders (not segregated).
  • Costs were required to be tracked at material level, and not at sales order level.

The main objective was to quickly provide the clients with goods from the stock. The main constraint was that real sales orders were often received from clients only for one day, and normally with just one day in advance or even the same day. Therefore, customer needed to produce goods without having the sales orders, as expecting the clients demand in future.

On this make-to-stock scenario, to avoid unreasonably high stock levels, a production plan is created in advance, and then you decide whether sales orders exceeding your plan are to affect production or not. Receiving sales orders as early as possible (using scheduling agreements, for example) also contributes to minimize high stock levels, but it was unrealistic on this customer, so a smooth demand forecast was key.

The production was determined by a production plan based on demand forecast (demand management), and only sales orders for first day exceeding the plan directly influenced production. If available, sales order information for subsequent days was required to be displayed for information purposes only (as normally info was uncompleted), but forecast was the demand driver except for the first day. Therefore, planning strategy used was net requirements planning on plant level (strategy 10), which allows to smooth the demand program.

Other very important considerations of the customer for achieving an effective materials planning were the following:

  • Customer wanted to expedite material planning with a more detailed collective material overview than the one provided by standard SAP S/4HANA MRP apps.
  • Customer requested to analyze materials on a dynamic periodic basis, mainly daily, but also weekly and monthly. The operative planning is usually managed by day, meanwhile medium-term planning should be managed by week/month.
  • Customer requested a calculation of stock coverage for every period displayed.
  • Customer worked with two planning modes: the real-time mode, like MD04 with the most up-to-date stock and requirements situation, and the fix-photo mode, similar to MD05 (MRP-List) with a snapshot at the beginning of the day with the situation of initial stock, requirements and receipts.
  • Customer did not plan materials at MRP areas level.
  • Customer needed a more flexible material selection by using the typical grouping fields available on material master.
  • Customer needed a flexible visualization of quantities in several units of measure.

Customer requirement for MRP monitoring was to build a new collective tool to evaluate and manage the MRP results for multiple materials. On this tool, future requirements would be displayed together with historical data, thus allowing the customer to compare future needs with past consumptions on the same period. Initial stock and final stock situation for every period based on total requirements and receipts were also required to be displayed.

Final decision was to create two similar planning monitoring tools: one focused on MPS products, the MPS Production Planning Monitor, and other focused on MRP products, the MRP Purchasing Planning Monitor. On this blog post we will focus on the MPS Production Planning Monitor, which is described in detail down below. The MRP Purchasing Planning Monitor was already explained on previous blog post Purchasing Planning Monitor for Collective Evaluation of MRP Planning Results.

Figure 1: Material Scope for MRP Live run with MPS/MRP materials.

 

Production Planning Monitor MPS

The Production Planning Monitor MPS was intended for displaying the stock/requirements/receipts situation for a particular or a series of materials, from the point of view of final production, that is, the final product to sale. The prerequisite was the MRP Live (operative production plan MPS & MRP) previously executed for the corresponding plant, and this was automatically done daily at night by a background job.

The evaluations on this Monitor display all receipt and issue elements for the materials in the form of a table and enable the planner to gain a quick overview of the stock/requirements/receipts situation for the material, as well as to branch into the detail list for the different MRP elements for this material. After a normal MPS&MRP run, the planner checks the stock/requirements/receipts situation for the materials, make necessary changes and ensures the availability of the materials for the next days, by creating production orders. The tool also allowed working by fixing the planning elements planned orders, but customer planners used to directly create the production orders.

As planners of this customer were old-school heavy users of SAP systems, this Monitor was developed in form of ALV list by using the BAPI_MATERIAL_STOCK_REQ_LIST function.

 

Selection Screen for Production Planning Monitor MPS

The selection screen of the new Production Planning Monitor MPS tool is displayed on below image (Figure 2):

Figure 2: Selection Screen of the Production Planning Monitor MPS tool.

 

The period of time to be considered must be selected using the fields “Date From” and “Date To”. One week is proposed by default.

Requirements/receipts can be shown by day, by week or by month: this is managed by field “Period Type”. The operative planning (short-term planning) is usually managed by day, while medium-term planning should be managed by week/month.

The materials to be shown can be selected by material type, material group, MRP controller, production scheduler, and/or material code.

 

The default “Planning Mode” is executed by using the fix photo of the initial stock (“Planning Fix-Photo”). Using this mode the entire requirements of the day and the entire production orders are shown. The other mode is the online planning which uses the current available stock on real-time (“Planning Real-Time”). Using this other mode only the pending requirements of the day and the pending production orders are shown.

The quantities shown can be displayed on any unit of measure available in the materials. The monitor allows to select the base unit of measure of the material, the kilograms or an alternative unit of measure to be entered by the user.

The total percentage of loss of the materials can be displayed as scrap (internal SAP), but also as drop or yield. This is just a percentage related to food processing to be considered by the planner during the evaluation process.

The production orders can be splitted on daily production and pre-production quantities, by ticking the indicator “Split Pre-Production”. This is just an option also related to food processing, to be considered by the planner during the evaluation process.

The calculation of stock coverage on periods can be dynamically changed to consider or not the “-Expired stock” and the “+Production”.

Finally, consumption history can be shown together with MRP data, for 1 period only or for 4 periods.

 

Output List for Production Planning Monitor MPS

An example of the output list of the new Production Planning Monitor MPS tool is displayed on below image (Figure 3):

Figure 3: Output List of the Production Planning Monitor MPS tool.

 

This new monitoring tool allows to display at the same time the following data:

  • MPS planning results over sales & forecast (future).
  • Consumption history (past).

The MRP evaluation on this Monitor displays all receipt and issue elements for every material in the form of a table and enable the planner to gain a quick overview of the stock/requirements/receipts situation for the material. Moreover, for every period the historical consumption for the material is shown for the fourth previous periods, and also the average. This allows the planner to compare future needs with past consumptions on the same period.

Requirements are shown in negative [- quantity] and receipts in positive [+ quantity], in order to ease the coverage understanding. A colour code red-yellow-green is used on field “Stock Final” to easily identify stock breaks.

This new tool also allows to branch into the detail list for the different MRP elements shown for the material, as well as for the available stock (initial), just with a double click on the corresponding cell.

The explanation of the meaning of the different columns of the new Production Planning Monitor MPS tool is summarized on below image (Figure 4):

Figure 4: Explanation of the Columns of the Production Planning Monitor MPS tool.

 

Displaying Options for Production Planning Monitor MPS

Requirements and receipts can be shown by day, by week or by month: this is managed by field “Period Type” on the selection screen. The operative planning is usually managed by day, while medium-term planning is managed by week/month.

Figure 5: Output List of the Production Planning Monitor MPS tool with Period Type by Week.

Figure 6: Output List of the Production Planning Monitor MPS tool with Period Type by Month.

 

The monitor has an option for avoiding displaying empty lines, thus planner being able to only focus on periods containing data.

Figure 7: Output List of the Production Planning Monitor MPS tool without empty lines.

 

The monitor also allows to branch into the detail list for the different MRP elements shown for the material, as well as for the available stock (initial), just with a double click on the corresponding cell. The available screens for the data details are the following:

  • With double-click on the initial stock cell of the first period (current period), you navigate to detail stock list.
  • With double-click on the sales orders cell, you navigate to detail sales orders requirements list.
  • With double-click on the sales forecast cell, you navigate to detail sales forecast requirements list.
  • With double-click on any receipts cell (manufacturing orders), you navigate to detail receipts list.
  • With double-click on any consumption cell, you navigate to detail historical consumption list.

Figure 8: Detail Stock List when double-clicking on the initial stock cell of the first period

Figure 9: Detail Requirements List when double-clicking on the Sales Orders cell

Figure 10: Detail Requirements List when double-clicking on the Sales Forecast cell

Figure 11: Detail Receipts List with Production Orders when double-clicking on any receipt cell (internal procurement material)

Figure 12: Detail Historical Consumption List when double-clicking on any consumption cell

 

The production orders can be splitted on daily production and pre-production quantities, by ticking the indicator “Split Pre-Production”. The concept of pre-production is something used on this plant to separate the production surplus of the previous day.

Figure 13: Output List of the Monitor with “Split Pre-Production” option.

 

The monitor has two planning modes: the fix-photo mode and the real-time mode, similar to classic MRP List (static) and Stocks/Requirements List (dynamic). The default planning mode is executed by using the fix photo of the initial stock (“Planning Fix-Photo”). Using this mode, the entire requirements of the day and the entire receipts (manufacturing) are shown. The other mode is the online planning which uses the current available stock on real-time (“Planning Real-Time”). Using this other mode, only the pending requirements of the day and the pending manufacturing orders are shown.

Figure 14: Output List of the Monitor for the different Planning Modes.

Figure 15: Output List with Details for the different Planning Modes.

 

The monitor can display the quantities on any unit of measure available in the materials. The monitor allows to select the base unit of measure of the material, the kilograms or an alternative unit of measure to be entered by the user. This can be done either on the selection screen or directly on the main screen, as well as the planning mode.

Figure 16: Output List of the Monitor showing quantities in different units of measure.

 

Action Buttons for Production Planning Monitor MPS

The Monitor has an action button to create a new production order (transaction CO01). Furthermore, on the different screens with the details list of receipts, when clicking on the production order, the monitor navigates to the corresponding maintenance application (transaction CO02), where the user can directly edit the date and/or the quantity. This considerably improves the number of clicks required to perform those actions compared to use new modes.

Figure 17: Output List of the Monitor with the action button “Create New Production Order”.

 

Helpful Links

entry.title: Realizan III Congreso Científico Nacional de Estudiantes de Contabilidad y el II Congreso Científico
entry.content:
Ver post original: Realizan III Congreso Científico Nacional de Estudiantes de Contabilidad y el II Congreso Científico Internacional de Estudiantes de Contabilidad de la Universidad de Panamá – Revista Hacia la Luz

uphacialaluz
17 octubre, 2025
2 minutos
 

La Facultad de Administración de Empresas y Contabilidad de la Universidad de Panamá, llevó a cabo el III Congreso Científico Nacional de Estudiantes de Contabilidad y el II Congreso Científico Internacional de Estudiantes de Contabilidad, eventos orientados a fomentar la investigación, el intercambio académico y la actualización profesional en el ámbito contable. Ambos encuentros se desarrollaron bajo el lema: “Innovación y Tecnología en la Contabilidad Moderna: Desafíos para el Profesional del Mañana”, y ofrecieron una variada programación de conferencias magistrales, ponencias estudiantiles y espacios de diálogo académico.

En un escenario global caracterizado por la creciente digitalización de los procesos empresariales y la continua transformación tecnológica del ámbito financiero, la formación de los futuros profesionales de la contabilidad implica la revisión y actualización de las competencias requeridas para su desempeño, herramientas y enfoques aplicados al ejercicio profesional. Conscientes de esta realidad, la Facultad de Administración de Empresas y Contabilidad organizó este congreso científico con el propósito de integrar la teoría y la práctica en torno a los avances tecnológicos que están redefiniendo la contabilidad moderna.

El evento reunió a destacados académicos, investigadores, profesionales y estudiantes del área contable, tanto a nivel nacional como internacional. Entre las actividades más destacadas se contó la conferencia del Ing. Carlos Cruz, Head of Solution Advisory Cloud ERP and Finance de la empresa SAP, quien presentó la ponencia titulada “SAP: Software de Gestión Financiera”. En su exposición, el ingeniero Cruz analizó las tendencias actuales en el uso de plataformas ERP  de SAP y soluciones en la nube para la optimización de los procesos financieros y contables, ofreciendo una visión práctica sobre la integración tecnológica en la gestión empresarial.

Desde el año 2024 la Universidad de Panamá cuenta con una alianza con SAP University Alliances para integrar las soluciones y recursos de SAP en su plan de estudios. Esta colaboración brinda a los estudiantes acceso a materiales educativos, software y la oportunidad de trabajar en desafíos empresariales reales, fortaleciendo así sus competencias y perspectivas profesionales en la economía digital. Este programa es una iniciativa global que busca reducir la brecha entre el mundo académico y el empresarial, proporcionando a docentes y estudiantes las más recientes tecnologías de SAP para el aprendizaje y la investigación. En la actualidad, más de 600 estudiantes de la Universidad de Panamá han recibido capacitación en la plataforma SAP.

La participación de expertos de alto nivel permitió a los asistentes conocer de primera mano las innovaciones que están transformando la contabilidad moderna, desde la automatización de procesos hasta la analítica avanzada y la aplicación de la inteligencia artificial en la gestión financiera.

entry.title: Enhancing Flexible Workflows for Purchase Requisitions in SAP S/4HANA Based on Sum of All Line Items
entry.content:
Introduction
In today’s dynamic procurement environments, organizations need workflow mechanisms that intelligently adapt to business changes without adding unnecessary administrative overhead.
SAP S/4HANA’s Flexible Workflow framework provides this adaptability — but sometimes, additional logic is required to differentiate approval levels based on the extent of change in a Purchase Requisition (PR).

This blog post explains how to extend the standard Flexible Workflow to trigger different approval levels depending on total PR price or amount variation.
The approach uses custom tables, BAdI implementations, and ABAP classes to intelligently decide when a workflow should restart — either with single-level or multi-level approval. 

Business Requirement

The requirement is to handle changes to a Purchase Requisition (PR) that has already been released. Depending on how much the PR value changes (Total/Sum of all line items), the workflow should determine whether to restart as a single-step or multi-step approval process.

Scenario Price / Amount Change Approval Behavior

Minor Change0.01% – 5% or Amount ≤ 25,000Trigger Single-Level approval
Major Change≥ 5% or Amount > 25,000Trigger All Levels (Standard)

This design ensures minor updates don’t require multiple approvals, while significant changes trigger the full approval chain.

Solution Overview

To achieve this dynamic behavior, we implemented the following components:

  1. Custom Table (ZTPMM_PR_LOG) – Stores workflow flag conditions (X or N).
  2. Custom Class (ZCL_PMM_PR_REL_STATUS) – Determines PR change type using change logs (CDHDR, CDPOS).
  3. BAdI Implementation (MM_PUR_S4_PR_WFL_RESTART) – Evaluates restart logic for Flexible Workflow.
  4. Condition Evaluation Class (ZCL_IM_PMM_WF_CONDITION_IMP) – Validates workflow start conditions.

 

Workflow Flow Diagram

Below diagram shows the complete flow of logic — from PR creation/change through workflow triggering.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Custom Table – ZTPMM_PR_LOG

We created a custom transparent table ZTPMM_PR_LOG to store workflow type flags and PR numbers.
This table acts as a control mechanism for determining workflow behavior.

Table Fields

Field Key Data Element Description

MANDT✔MANDTClient
BANFN✔BANFNPurchase Requisition Number
WFTYP ZDE_PMM_WFTYPWorkflow Type (X = Single, N = Multi)

 

Determining Change Type – Class ZCL_PMM_PR_REL_STATUS

This class identifies change details from PR change logs (CDHDR, CDPOS) to determine whether a modification is significant.
It compares previous vs current values and calculates the percentage difference.
If the difference falls within or exceeds defined thresholds, it updates ZTPMM_PR_LOG accordingly.

*--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
* Class Name:  ZCL_PMM_PR_REL_STATUS
* Author : Shravankumar Tiwari
* PR Approval Workflow - Get PR status single or Multi level flag
* im_ebeln = importing parameter in class
*--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  METHOD get_pr_status.

    CONSTANTS :
      lc_objectclas     TYPE cdhdr-objectclas VALUE 'BANF',
      lc_tabname_eban   TYPE cdpos-tabname VALUE 'EBAN',
      lc_fname_frgzu    TYPE cdpos-fname VALUE 'FRGZU',
      lc_chngind_u      TYPE cdpos-chngind VALUE 'U'.


    TYPES: BEGIN OF lty_cdchange,
             mandant    TYPE cdpos-mandant,
             objectclas TYPE cdpos-objectclas,
             objectid   TYPE cdpos-objectid,
             changenr   TYPE cdpos-changenr,
             tabkey     TYPE cdpos-tabkey,
             fname      TYPE cdpos-fname,
             chngind    TYPE cdpos-chngind,
             value_old  TYPE cdpos-value_old,
             value_new  TYPE cdpos-value_new,
             username   TYPE cdhdr-username,
             udate      TYPE cdhdr-udate,
             utime      TYPE cdhdr-utime,
             tcode      TYPE cdhdr-tcode,
           END OF lty_cdchange.

    DATA: lt_cdpos     TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF lty_cdchange,
          lt_cdhdr_top TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF cdhdr,
          lt_cdpos_raw TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF cdpos,
          lv_purchaser TYPE ebeln.

    " Step 1: Get last 2 entries from CDHDR
    SELECT * FROM cdhdr
      INTO TABLE lt_cdhdr_top
     WHERE objectclas = lc_objectclas
       AND objectid   = im_ebeln 
     ORDER BY udate DESCENDING, utime DESCENDING
     .

    SORT lt_cdhdr_top BY udate DESCENDING utime DESCENDING.
    DELETE lt_cdhdr_top FROM 3.   " keep only the first 2 rows

    " Step 2: Get CDPOS entries that match CHANGENR from the above
    LOOP AT lt_cdhdr_top INTO DATA(ls_cdhdr).
      SELECT * FROM cdpos
        INTO TABLE lt_cdpos_raw                         "#EC CI_NOORDER
       WHERE objectclas = ls_cdhdr-objectclas
         AND objectid   = ls_cdhdr-objectid
         AND changenr   = ls_cdhdr-changenr
         AND tabname    = lc_tabname_eban
         AND fname      = lc_fname_frgzu
         AND chngind    = lc_chngind_u .

      LOOP AT lt_cdpos_raw INTO DATA(ls_pos).
        APPEND VALUE lty_cdchange(
          mandant     = ls_pos-mandant
          objectclas  = ls_pos-objectclas
          objectid    = ls_pos-objectid
          changenr    = ls_pos-changenr
          tabkey      = ls_pos-tabkey
          fname       = ls_pos-fname
          chngind     = ls_pos-chngind
          value_old   = ls_pos-value_old
          value_new   = ls_pos-value_new
          username    = ls_cdhdr-username
          udate       = ls_cdhdr-udate
          utime       = ls_cdhdr-utime
          tcode       = ls_cdhdr-tcode
        ) TO lt_cdpos.
      ENDLOOP.
    ENDLOOP.

**addional check for change case
    SELECT SINGLE *
      FROM ztpmm_pr_log
      INTO (ls_ztpmm_pr_log)
      WHERE banfn = im_ebeln.

    """Validate the records
    READ TABLE lt_cdpos INTO DATA(ls_cfpos1) INDEX 1. "Latest record
    DELETE lt_cdpos WHERE tabkey NE ls_cfpos1-tabkey.     
    READ TABLE lt_cdpos INTO DATA(ls_cfpos2) INDEX 2. "Old record
    IF  ls_cfpos1-value_old IS NOT INITIAL AND ls_cfpos2-value_new IS NOT INITIAL
      AND ls_ztpmm_pr_log-wftyp  = wc_x.
      ex_flag = wc_x. "single level
    ELSE.
      ex_flag = wc_n. "Multiple level
    ENDIF.

  ENDMETHOD.

💡Tip: The same logic can be extended for other purchasing documents like Purchase Orders (POs).

Restart Logic – BAdI Implementation  

We used BAdI MM_PUR_S4_PR_WFL_RESTART to define the restart conditions for Flexible Workflow.
The following ABAP logic automatically determines if the workflow should restart as single-level (X) or multi-level (N).

(Notes :

  1. Variable lv_curr_total_value and lv_prev_total_value we need to sum all PR line items price from purchasereqitemscure and purchasereqitemsprev. We can create new static attribute table in class and fill information e.g. gt_purchasereqitemscurr and gt_purchasereqitemsprev  global table name
  2. Function module - ZFMPMM_RFC_PR_WF_ZUPD is remote enabled FM we update ztpmm_pr_log custom table from structure ls_ztpmm_pr_log )

"--------------------------------------------------------------------
"*  Custom Logic for Restarting Flexible Workflow for Purchase Requisition
"*  Author : Shravankumar Tiwari
"*  Description : Determines workflow restart logic based on price
"*                 or amount change thresholds (minor vs major)
"--------------------------------------------------------------------

CONSTANTS : 
  lc_x       TYPE wfl_restart VALUE  'X',
  lc_plus_5  TYPE p DECIMALS 2 VALUE '5',
  lc_plus_01 TYPE p DECIMALS 2 VALUE '0.01',           
  lc_rfc     TYPE rfcdest  VALUE 'NONE'.

DATA :
  lv_item_value       TYPE p DECIMALS 2,
  lv_prev_total_value TYPE p DECIMALS 2,
  lv_curr_total_value TYPE p DECIMALS 2,
  lv_diff             TYPE p DECIMALS 2,
  lv_percent          TYPE p DECIMALS 2,
  ls_ztpmm_pr_log     TYPE ztpmm_pr_log, 
  lv_flag             TYPE abap_bool.

"--------------------------------------------------------------------
" Calculate % difference between old and new PR values
"--------------------------------------------------------------------
lv_diff = lv_curr_total_value - lv_prev_total_value.
lv_percent = ( lv_diff / lv_prev_total_value ) * 100.

"--------------------------------------------------------------------
" Check if difference exceeds thresholds (>5% or >25,000)
"--------------------------------------------------------------------
IF lv_percent > lc_plus_5 OR lv_diff > 25000.        
  lv_flag = abap_true.
  ls_ztpmm_pr_log-banfn = purchasereqitemscurr-purchaserequisition.
  ls_ztpmm_pr_log-wftyp = wc_n. "Multiple level
ENDIF.

"--------------------------------------------------------------------
" Check for minor changes (0.01%–4.99% or ≤25,000) → Single level
"--------------------------------------------------------------------
IF lv_flag = abap_false AND
  ( ( lv_percent BETWEEN lc_plus_01 AND lc_plus_5 ) OR
    ( lv_diff BETWEEN lc_plus_01 AND 25000 ) ).
  ls_ztpmm_pr_log-banfn = purchasereqitemscurr-purchaserequisition.
  ls_ztpmm_pr_log-wftyp = wc_x. "X = Single level
  lv_flag = abap_true.
ENDIF.

"-------------------------------------------------------------------- 
" Trigger restart if major change detected
"--------------------------------------------------------------------
IF lv_flag = abap_true.
  restartworkflow = lc_x.
  "Store WF indicator for PR: X = Single, N = Multiple
  CALL FUNCTION 'ZFMPMM_RFC_PR_WF_ZUPD' DESTINATION lc_rfc  
    EXPORTING
      im_ztpmm_pr_log = ls_ztpmm_pr_log.
ENDIF.

Logic Summary

Condition Workflow Type Approval Level

> 5% or > 25,000NMulti-Level
0.01%–4.99% or ≤ 25,000XSingle-Level

 

Workflow Start Condition – Fiori Configuration

We configured two Flexible Workflow variants in the Fiori app “Manage Workflows for Purchase Requisitions”, each linked to a specific start condition based on the ZTPMM_PR_LOG flag.

Single-Level Approval (Flag ‘X’)

Triggers a single-step approval when the Creation Indicator = ‘X’.

Multi-Level Approval (Flag ‘N’)

Triggers three sequential approvals (Procurement, Project Control, Budget Owner) when the Creation Indicator = ‘N’.

Conditional Evaluation – Dynamic Workflow Trigger

In the method IF_SWF_FLEX_IFS_CONDITION_EVAL~EVALUATE_CONDITION of class
ZCL_IM_PMM_WF_CONDITION_IMP, we dynamically evaluate workflow start parameters to determine if the condition should be true.

"--------------------------------------------------------------------
"  **Author : Shravankumar Tiwari
" Conditional Evaluation – Dynamic Workflow Trigger
"--------------------------------------------------------------------

METHOD if_swf_flex_ifs_condition_eval~evaluate_condition.
  LOOP AT it_parameter_value INTO ls_param_value.
    CASE ls_param_value-name.
      WHEN 'CreationIndicator'.
        READ TABLE lt_purchaserequisition INTO DATA(ls_purreq) INDEX 1.

        zcl_pmm_pr_rel_status=>get_pr_status(
          EXPORTING im_ebeln = ls_purreq-purchaserequisition
          IMPORTING ex_flag  = lv_flag_2
        ).

        IF ls_param_value-value EQ lv_flag_2.
          cv_is_true = abap_true.
        ELSE.
          cv_is_true = abap_false.
        ENDIF.

      WHEN OTHERS.
        cv_is_true = abap_false.
    ENDCASE.
  ENDLOOP.
ENDMETHOD.

Key Benefits

✅Efficiency – Avoid redundant approvals for minor PR changes
✅Scalability – Extendable to other workflow objects
✅Transparency – Logs stored in ZTPMM_PR_LOG
✅User-Friendly – Maintained via Fiori, no coding required

Conclusion:  This enhancement enables organizations to make their SAP S/4HANA Flexible Workflow truly adaptive and business-aware.
By combining custom ABAP logic, Fiori configuration, and workflow extensibility, we achieve a balanced approach to automation and control. 

Thank you for learning.
